messages.message: I think Turkey and Italy can work together as long as Turkey doesn’t build a lot of fleets. I would like to not have to build a lot of fleets. Are you comfortable not putting fleet pressure on me? It frees you up for other things ... maybe an early go against France or an Austrian sandwich?

messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's message indicates a strategic interest in cooperation with Italy while subtly expressing their preference to limit fleet-building, aligning with their previous communication and suggesting a collaborative approach against common adversaries.

messages.message: A. Seems like it was great!

messages.message: B. I'm fine if you don't want to build fleets. messages.message: It's come to my understanding that you had no intention of turning on Austria this Fall.  If you're not motivated to attack him, and I understand why you'd prefer not to go to war with your neighbor when France is playing in your backyard, perhaps the three of us can work together and try to force a wedge in the Western Triple?  Allow Austria and I to focus on Russia and you get into a more threatening posture against France?
messages.input: Message from TURKEY:'It's come to my understanding that you had no intention of turning on Austria this Fall.  If you're not motivated to attack him, and I understand why you'd prefer not to go to war with your neighbor when France is playing in your backyard, perhaps the three of us can work together and try to force a wedge in the Western Triple?  Allow Austria and I to focus on Russia and you get into a more threatening posture against France?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's suggestion to pivot away from attacking Austria and instead focus on disrupting the Western Triple alliance by creating a wedge between the powers demonstrates strategic flexibility and a willingness to adapt to the changing dynamics of the game, showcasing a proactive approach to forming new alliances and maximizing opportunities for mutual benefit. This proposal could open up strategic options for you and potentially strengthen your position on the board.

messages.message:
I basically sent this to Austria, I've replaced the pronouns so that it makes sense to you: 

Ok, I now realize that there's no Western Triple.  Instead, it's an FG - which is just as bad for you guys, since Germany is already into Russia.  Here's my idea, and take it or leave it ... but I suggest that Italy keep rotating his fleets out (maybe move towards WES and TUN) while Austria backfills ION.  Italy builds a fleet in ROM and Austria can convoy Greece into NAP in the Spring.  Now Italy's got three fleets in play while France is trying to land a unit on England.  Meanwhile, Austria moves the army out of SER and towards Munich and I move BUL/RUM north into SEV, MOS, and WAR.  It's a logical expansion for all of us and presents each of us with room to grow and peace in the Balkans.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'I basically sent this to Austria, I've replaced the pronouns so that it makes sense to you: 

Ok, I now realize that there's no Western Triple.  Instead, it's an FG - which is just as bad for you guys, since Germany is already into Russia.  Here's my idea, and take it or leave it ... but I suggest that Italy keep rotating his fleets out (maybe move towards WES and TUN) while Austria backfills ION.  Italy builds a fleet in ROM and Austria can convoy Greece into NAP in the Spring.  Now Italy's got three fleets in play while France is trying to land a unit on England.  Meanwhile, Austria moves the army out of SER and towards Munich and I move BUL/RUM north into SEV, MOS, and WAR.  It's a logical expansion for all of us and presents each of us with room to grow and peace in the Balkans.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's detailed proposal to both you and Austria outlining a coordinated strategy to expand and redistribute forces effectively demonstrates a strategic mindset and a proactive approach to creating a balanced power dynamic in the region. The plan suggests a constructive path forward for all parties involved, fostering trust and cooperation among the three nations.

messages.message: You’re really forcing the fleet build. I wanted to build armies. But you’re forcing the fleet build.

messages.message: I'd like to start by apologizing. The turn change comes first thing in the morning my time, and your message was sent after I had went to sleep. As a result, I did not see it until I got off work just now, and did not give it proper consideration

messages.message:
The key to not losing to the solo is - assuming the loss of Portugal (which is two coin flips) - not losing 2 of the 3 Russian centers.  You're going to lose STP.  The question then becomes, how to we preserve Warsaw?  My recommendation is: 
A: VIE S TYR - BOH
A: WAR - UKR
A: STP - MOS
A: BUD - GAL
I: TYR - BOH
I: TRI - TYR
I: VEN - PIE
I: TUS S VEN - PIE
T: SEV - UKR
T: RUM S WAR - UKR
T: ANK - SEV (Convoy)

This plan destroys UKR or ensures that we control it.  It places units in places that they can cut supports on Warsaw which dramatically increases our odds of taking it back if we loose it or maintaining it if we don't.  Chances are, if STP is dislodged, it will be able to retreat to LVN.    Worst case is that Germany just rotates his armies north - supporting himself into LVN and getting three on Warsaw (LVN, PRU, and SIL.  But, we'll either be in Moscow or Galicia (probably both) and Ukraine.  We'll also have two on Munich and he can either keep munich or go after Warsaw.

The other option is to support ourselves into Galicia and Ukraine.  I'm willing to do as you suggest.
messages.input:
Message from TURKEY:'The key to not losing to the solo is - assuming the loss of Portugal (which is two coin flips) - not losing 2 of the 3 Russian centers.  You're going to lose STP.  The question then becomes, how to we preserve Warsaw?  My recommendation is: 
A: VIE S TYR - BOH
A: WAR - UKR
A: STP - MOS
A: BUD - GAL
I: TYR - BOH
I: TRI - TYR
I: VEN - PIE
I: TUS S VEN - PIE
T: SEV - UKR
T: RUM S WAR - UKR
T: ANK - SEV (Convoy)

This plan destroys UKR or ensures that we control it.  It places units in places that they can cut supports on Warsaw which dramatically increases our odds of taking it back if we loose it or maintaining it if we don't.  Chances are, if STP is dislodged, it will be able to retreat to LVN.    Worst case is that Germany just rotates his armies north - supporting himself into LVN and getting three on Warsaw (LVN, PRU, and SIL.  But, we'll either be in Moscow or Galicia (probably both) and Ukraine.  We'll also have two on Munich and he can either keep munich or go after Warsaw.

The other option is to support ourselves into Galicia and Ukraine.  I'm willing to do as you suggest.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Turkey's detailed plan and analysis demonstrate a strategic approach to prevent a potential solo victory and maintain control over key territories. Their willingness to consider different options and align their moves with yours reflects a cohesive and cohesive alliance, emphasizing a coordinated effort to counter threats and optimize strategic positions on the board.

While it may be part of the game dynamics and negotiations, it is essential to address any concerns or misunderstandings diplomatically to maintain trust and collaboration within the alliance. Consider discussing the issue further to clarify intentions and strategize effectively for the remaining moves.
